Turns to Adrian for support amidst the clamor and physical collapse.

Collapses suddenly from apparent physical weakness or injury immediately after the fight, showing possible overexertion or failure to maintain his condition.
Reassures others despite being physically weak and in distress, asks Adrian to stay with him.
Refuses hospital at first, insists he is fine, to avoid worrying others.
Despite severe physical distress and weakness, he tries to reassure others he is fine and resists immediate medical help.

Remembers the lessons from Mickey about willpower and skill, indicating internalization of past training and confidence.
Acknowledges the unique qualities of his past and his father’s special mentorship, but struggles to reconcile that with the present reality of his son's approach to boxing.
Hugs Adrian and his son and walks off together as a family unit.
Encourages Tommy before the fight by acknowledging his nerves and showing understanding.
Tells Paulie and Jimmy to leave Tommy alone when he needs a minute.
Encourages Tommy to overcome fear and self-doubt, assures him he has the tools to win.
Tells Tommy to talk about his troubles later, focusing on the fight now.
Encourages Tommy to overcome fear and focus on his fight plan, emphasizing calm confidence and self-belief.
Responds to Tommy’s mental struggle with practical advice and reassurance, shifting focus to fighting mindset rather than distractions.
Says 'Good luck' to Union Cane, a rival fighter, showing sportsmanship and sincerity.
Nods at Adrian and Rocky Jr. as he passes, indicating a respectful and warm connection with family.
Does not engage with Tommy’s antagonistic behavior, does not escalate tension.
Steps forward to greet the crowd, acknowledging his status as a respected ex-champion confidently.
Calmly wishes Union Cane good luck, showing sportsmanship and confidence in social engagement.
Appears puzzled and confused when Tommy urges him to hold up the fight, indicating possible lack of assertiveness or awareness in the situation.
Comments on Tommy's nervousness to Paulie and Jimmy, showing an understanding of others' feelings.
Questions Tommy’s attitude ('What's the matter with you?'), indicating concern or disapproval of his aggressive demeanor.
Recognizes and assesses Tommy's nervousness calmly during the fight buildup.
Does not engage in trash talk or show aggressive confidence like Tommy, instead exhibits quiet observation.
Reassures Tommy by acknowledging their shared nervousness and advises him to be a class act like Apollo.
Encourages Tommy calmly, acknowledges nerves, advises patience and class based on Apollo's style.
Upset emotionally climbing through ropes upon Tommy's response, indicating personal distress.
Does not interfere negatively during fight, allows Tommy to fight his own fight while observing.
Gives clear, specific advice to Jimmy and Paulie to move side to side and tie up the opponent to avoid getting hit by a hook.
Encourages Cane to focus on fighting rather than talking, showing focus and practical coaching.
Urges Tommy to end the fight when Cane is clearly beaten, exhibiting a concern for sportsmanship and control.
Trains Tommy and gives tactical advice to avoid excessive brutality, displaying skill and thoughtful mentorship.
Allows Tommy to take over and effectively relinquishes control of the fight strategy to him, showing trust in Tommy's capability.
Does not intervene or stop the fight despite seeing Tommy 'playing the crowd' and the champion being savagely beaten, indicating possible passivity or detachment.
Gives instructions to Tommy to carry Union Cane instead of finishing him off.
Walks away quietly as Duke takes over the post-fight interview, allowing others to dominate the scene.
Gives strategic instructions to Tommy to not finish the opponent quickly, showing restraint and tactical thinking.
Is stunned and unable to respond when Tommy reveals he was only following Rocky's orders, indicating a momentary lapse or surprise.
Allows Duke to dominate the post-fight scene and walks away without asserting himself, suggesting passivity or loss of control over the situation.
Goes to Cane, apologizes for the injury, acknowledges his status as a fighter.
Dismisses the wife’s plea by saying Union is not his 'boy' anymore, creating emotional distance.
Keeps silent and focused when fans call out his name, showing emotional restraint but limited friendliness.
Shows concern for Cane's condition and offers words of comfort despite the tense situation.
Denies paternal connection to Union by saying 'He's not my boy no more' when confronted by Cane’s wife.
Remains lost in thought after Cane is taken away on the stretcher, indicating possible internal conflict or uncertainty.
Keeps attention focused and ignores fans calling out to him, showing focus and restraint.
Moves confidently through a thickening crowd and bypasses security guards without hesitation or disturbance.
Appears out of place in a glamorous event wearing casual, unpolished attire like a leather jacket and hat.
Focuses his attention on finding Tommy Gunn in a distracting, noisy environment with media and social distractions.
Expresses deep emotional hurt and disappointment toward Tommy, trying to salvage their friendship.
Explodes in anger, showing his pain and frustration but still voices desire for things to be good between them.
Does not retaliate harshly against Tommy's dismissal and harsh words, internally acknowledges Tommy’s success without bitterness.
Expresses his emotional hurt and disappointment about his relationship with Tommy, showing awareness of interpersonal dynamics but struggles to effectively resolve conflict.
Confronts Tommy about the betrayal and the damage done to Cane, indicating some courage but lacks strategic communication, escalating tensions.
Does not successfully manage the conversation or demonstrate leadership to de-escalate the situation or assert control.
Decides not to escalate the conflict by turning away and refusing to hit Tommy.
Engages in a fight after provocation by Tommy, including exchanging hits.
Decides to walk away from a confrontation with Tommy instead of escalating the fight.
Engages in a physical fight with Tommy after initially trying to avoid it.
Starts to take off his jacket as if prepared to defend himself or continue the fight.
Begins to circle as Tommy drives several lefts in his face, then charges into Tommy with both hands digging into Tommy’s body.
Backs into the center of the room and charges Tommy despite being driven back and hit hard, showing resilience and tactical aggression.
Takes a knee to midsection and a hard chop to the neck that results in crashing through swinging doors, indicating momentary loss of control or underestimation of Tommy’s aggression.
Says to Tommy, 'I loved ya, man! Get out while ya can fight — ya ain't provin' nothin'...'
Responds to Tommy's taunts with 'I never wanted to.' showing restraint rather than aggression.
Acknowledges respect for Tommy despite fighting him: 'Look at us! Like dogs fightin’. I respected ya.'
Dodges trash cans thrown at him and continues fighting despite a distorted vision and physical exhaustion.
Does not seem to fully engage in the fight with Tommy competitively, stating 'I never wanted to' beat him, and backing away wearily.
Shows emotional intelligence and insight by acknowledging respect for Tommy and trying to get him to leave the fight before causing damage.
Holds Tommy by the throat ready to deliver a final blow but searches his eyes, then releases and backs away instead of finishing him.
Charges forward, ducks beneath three wild swings, and clips Tommy in the jaw.
Manages to trade blows when nearly on his feet despite fatigue.
Leaps high and lands a flush chin shot making Tommy stumble back.
Delivers hook after hook to pin Tommy against the bus and prepares to deliver a final blow.
Holds Tommy by the throat, searches his eyes, then releases grip and backs away instead of finishing him.
Acknowledges Adrian and Rocky Jr.'s importance, expresses care and gratitude.
Rejects Tommy's request to come back despite Tommy admitting mistakes and asking sincerely.
Responds calmly and kindly to supporters praising his performance.
Prioritizes family and personal responsibilities over past conflicts or attachments.
Reassures his son by encouraging him to train together, showing support and encouragement.
Acknowledges and respects Adrian's refusal firmly, showing respect for his wife's boundaries.
Jokes that you don’t fight with your mother because she’s the toughest person, showing a friendly and affectionate tone.
Dismisses worries about his son’s readiness by reassuring him confidently and respects his wife's authoritative refusal on training.
